p: Although utilization is most common in rural settings to sustain local livelihoods, Prosopis products are also exploited on a large scale by private companies. In South Africa, pods are collected to produce organic medicines (‘manna’) that are said to have properties that stabilize blood sugar levels in humans. This company is making profits of US$100 000 per annum and has the potential to increase profits 10-fold if the product is marketed internationally ( Wise et al. 2012 ). A company in Brazil, Riocon, has an annual turnover of US$6 million a year from the sale of Prosopis pod flour for animal feeds (A. Davi, Ricocon, pers. comm.).
